description: The Devon Energy Corporation has offered $140 million to the Hondo Oil and Gas Company for most of Hondo's domestic oil and gas reserves and seven natural gas processing plants. Adjustments for reserves produced and cash flow from operations before to closing are expected to reduce the net purchase price to $130 million, Devon said.

title: E.P.A. Is Called Lax With Contractor
description: The Inspector General of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that mismanagement had enabled the agency's largest contractor to gain control of virtually all of its computerized information systems and may have led to millions of dollars in improper payments to the company.

title: G.D.P. Gain Is Revised Up to 0.8%
description: The nation's economy grew at a faster rate in the fourth quarter than was previously reported, the Government said today, but the pace of growth was still sluggish.

title: Pan Am Doesn't Deserve Any Sort of Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: An 'Unknown Quantity' Heads the Welsh Opera
description: Nearly every major British opera company has had a new chief administrator appointed in the last year. But no appointment caused greater comment than that of Matthew Epstein in August as general director of the Welsh National Opera.

title: Money Stuck In the Muck
description: In the Old World, there are great harbors of ancient civilizations that are completely silted up. They are popular with tourists. Ostia, the port of the Rome of the Caesars, is no longer even on the sea. Such ports are bleak evidence of the disappearance of a way of life and of unalterable natural processes. The U.S. may be the first nation in history to let such a thing happen to its largest ports while they are still of immense value. And our reason will not be nature but rather the fear of consequences of man-made pollution.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Arditti String Quartet Merkin Concert Hall

title: Justice Dept. Clears Merger Of 2 Big West Coast Banks
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, by promising to increase the number of branches and amount of deposits it will divest itself of, has obtained the Justice Department's approval for its pending acquisition of the Security Pacific Corporation.

title: Corrections
description: Listings on Wednesday and Thursday showing the winners at the 34th annual Grammy Awards ceremony on Tuesday at Radio City Music Hall rendered the name of a producer of "The Civil War" soundtrack recording incorrectly. He is John Colby.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans; Republican Duel: A Party Wounded
description: Patrick J. Buchanan's challenge to President Bush is threatening to turn an orderly, behind-the-scenes struggle over the future of the Republican Party into an open civil war, Administration officials and senior Republican strategists say.

title: Your Money; An Alternative To Chasing Yields
description: BECAUSE of the plunge in interest rates in the last year, many Americans are searching for investments with higher yields than the 4 or 5 percent that now typifies certificates of deposit, money market funds and similar conservative holdings. But in doing so, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants says, many are overlooking a more useful financial strategy: pay down consumer debt.

title: Review/Dance; An Apollo Noble Yet Eager, With Other Earthly Traits
description: New casts in familiar works marked the New York City Ballet's weekend performances, with the most impressive featuring Peter Boal in the title role of George Balanchine's "Apollo" on Sunday afternoon.

title: Who's the Phone For? Depends on the Ring
description: Anyone with teen-agers in the house knows how annoying it can be to pick up a ringing phone only to find out, once again, that it's not for you. Or if you have small children, you understand how embarrassing it can be to get a business call and discover that your 4-year-old has already picked up the receiver and explained that you are in the bath or yelling at your spouse.

title: Fighting Irish, Marching Irish
description: The standoff between the Ancient Order of Hibernians and the Irish Lesbian and Gay Organization should not be seen primarily as a clash between gays and the Roman Catholic Church. The battle over whether gays and lesbians should be allowed to march in the New York City St. Patrick's Day Parade on March 17 should be viewed instead as a generational collision between two groups of Irish emigrants, the undercurrents of which stretch all the way back to Ireland and pit the immigrants generation of the 1980's against those who came to the U.S. in the 1950's.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House; WHITE HOUSE SAYS BUCHANAN IS LIKELY TO REMAIN IN RACE
description: The White House said today there was a prospect that Patrick J. Buchanan could carry his challenge to President Bush through the California primary. The President's spokesman said a quarter or more of Republicans seem inclined to vote against Mr. Bush to symbolize their unhappiness over the economy.

title: They Live Undeterred By Turner's Syndrome
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Check Is Not in the Mail
description: The mail is missing. You were expecting a Social Security check, say, or a credit card or driver's license. Has it been lost or stolen?

title: Patents; For Haters Of Jangling Pocket Cash
description: ALTHOUGH futurists have predicted for decades that a cashless society was at hand, the fact remains that stray coins still weigh down pockets and collect in jars, drawers and at the bottom of purses.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Cynthia Phelps Violist Weill Recital Hall

title: U.S. Aid to Russians: Thanks and Touch of Shame
description: "And this?" said Rosa V. Nikolotova, extracting a can of hot chili with beans from a box that landed this afternoon at her son's school on a wave of good will, sent "To Russia With Love" by schoolchildren in northern California. "What might this be?"

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Challenger; As Acid-Tongued Buchanan Lashes Out, Ambiguity Is the Last Unpardonable Sin
description: Angered, piqued and stung by the Bush campaign's concentrated new effort to paint him as an unqualified, unelectable, upstart Presidential challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan is responding in kind -- and then some.

title: Tests for Chamberlain
description: WILT CHAMBERLAIN will remain hospitalized for the next few days to undergo tests to find the cause of an irregular heartbeat, his doctor said yesterday.

title: Treasury Note and Bond Prices Rise
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates fell in moderately active trading yesterday, as dealers reacted positively to a number of reports that suggest the economy remains quite weak.

title: Marion F. Schappel, A Bank Executive, 67
description: Marion F. Schappel, a retired vice president at Citibank and one of the first women there to reach that rank, died on Wednesday at her home in Somers, N.Y. She was 67 years old.

title: Review/Theater; Looking At Life As a Play (A Comedy)
description: Using the theater as a metaphor for life is hardly a literary innovation, but no contemporary playwright has applied it to the slings and arrows, not to mention absurdities, of modern existence with such penetrating humor as David Mamet in his gem of a play, "A Life in the Theater," which is being given a fond revival at the Jewish Repertory Theater.

title: Ciba to Pay New Jersey For Illegal Waste Dumping
description: In a court-approved settlement, the Ciba-Geigy Corporation agreed today to pay New Jersey $62 million to end seven years of litigation over the giant chemical company's violation of state environmental regulations at its Toms River plant.

title: Esprit de Corps Names A New Chief Executive
description: Esprit de Corps, a leading sportswear company based in San Francisco, said yesterday that Fritz Ammann had been named president and chief executive, effective April 1. Mr. Ammann has most recently been chief executive of Charles Jourdan and its affiliated companies in Paris, and was previously chief executive of Swatch.

title: New York City Delays Billing Non-City Cabs
description: With tensions building in the fiscal border war between New York City and its suburbs, the city has temporarily backed away from one plan to raise revenues from nonresidents to help balance its budget.

title: One Killed And 3 Injured In a Shooting In a Pool Hall
description: One man was killed and three others were wounded when gunfire erupted in a pool hall on East 12th Street in lower Manhattan last night, the police said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Browning-Ferris Industries, Houston, a solid and chemical waste company, received a $210 million contract from the City of Philadelphia to dispose of its municipal solid waste. * Mid Am Inc., Bowling Green, Ohio, a financial services holding company, and Ultra Bancorp, Xenia, Ohio, a savings holding company, entered a preliminary merger agreement under which Ultra will be merged into a newly formed subsidiary of Mid Am.

title: Sports of The Times; The Twists And Turns of Carl Lewis
description: Who is Carl Lewis, really?

title: Educators and Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Has Long Poked Its Nose in the Arts; One Man's Vulgarity
description: To the Editor:

title: China's Somewhat Capitalist Road
description: Beijing newspaper commentaries this week signal a new drive by Deng Xiaoping to put China back on the capitalist road, ending a two-and-a-half-year detour into Socialist stagnation. Mr. Deng's new course deserves American encouragement but not blind support.

title: The Message of Millicent's Death
description: How well do New York City authorities protect children? The question arises once again because of the recent death of 6-year-old Millicent Ayala, allegedly at the hands of her aunt and foster mother. The question is depressingly hard to answer because the state's confidentiality law limits access to information in child abuse cases. As this tragedy demonstrates anew, the law needs reform.
